title: How romance ruined love
intro: In this programme Neil and Dan will be discussing romance, as well as teaching you 6 new items of vocabulary.
this_week_question: When was the start of the romantic period? Was it...
a) The beginning of the 18th century,
b) the middle of the 18th century
or c) the end of the 18th century?
You'll hear the answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: group of people working together to support an idea
the spirit of a particular time
a standard from which other things are judged
(thing) an, often imagined, perfect version of something
the important or practical detail involved in a situation or thing
a thing which is imperfect in some way

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English– the show that brings you an interesting topic, authentic listening practice and vocabulary to help you improve your language skills. I'm Dan…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. In this programme we'll be discussing romance, as well as teaching you 6 new items of vocabulary, of course . Now, Dan, why are you looking so upset?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Oh Neil, it's all over! She broke up with me on Valentine's Day! She said I wasn't the one.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Cheer up Dan, cheer up. It's not your fault.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: No?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You can blame romanticism.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Romanticism? What's that?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Romanticism was a movement that started in Europe and spread worldwide. It influenced literature, art, poetry, music and the way people behaved.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: A movement meaning 'a group of people working together to support an idea'?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. And that bring us on to this week's question. When was the start of the romantic period? Was it a) the beginning of the 18th century, b) the middle of the 18th century or c) the end of the 18th century?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, I honestly have no idea, so I'm going to go smack in the middle… the middle of the 18th century.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And we'll find out later on in the show if you got the question right. Now, going back to your ex-girlfriend, let me take a wild guess… love at first sight, was it?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well… yes. What's your point?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, it's not your fault, Dan. The idea is romantic, and by that I mean it originated from the romantic era. It was part of the zeitgeist , and many of these ideas still continue today.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Zeitgeist - the word comes from German and literally means 'the spirit of the time'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A lot of what we believe about love today – for example, the idea that two people will live happily ever after - comes from the romantic period.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: But, everyone loves a bit of romance!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's true. However, it's one thing to enjoy romance, but it can be dangerous to judge your relationship against romantic ideals.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: True, it might not be a realistic benchmark , and by that I mean 'a standard from which other things are judged'. So we grow up hearing these romantic stories, which leads us to develop an idea of what a relationship is meant to be… and then we get disappointed by the real thing?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, to put it bluntly, yes. The romantic ideal is just that – an idealised version, or perfect version, of a relationship. But it often leaves out the nitty-gritty , meaning 'practical details'. Details like work, stress, children… all of the things that we have to deal with in everyday life.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Not to mention, the fact that everyone is flawed , or imperfect, in their own way. That means we get angry or moody or upset for all sorts of reasons.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Exactly! Many popular love stories end at the point where the characters get together or marry. But very few show us how to keep that someone special over a long period of time. A relationship is hard work.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And if the relationship you are in isn't as perfect as the story said it should be, then maybe you're with the wrong person, which could explain why so many marriages end in divorce. I wonder if that's true for other people's relationships. Fortunately, I found some people with partners and asked them.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I asked these people about theirs…

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Vox Pops Is your partner 100% perfect for you? No. Not 100%. No, I don't think that's true.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Does that mean true love doesn't exist?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No. It just means that all relationships must be worked on and that perfection is impossible. But we should never give up trying.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: You're right! She wasn't the one for me! I need to find my next Juliet. She'll be just perfect!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh Dan. You haven't learnt anything! You're just a hopeless romantic. Now, can you remember the quiz question? I asked you when the Romantic period originated: was it a) the beginning of the 18th century, b) the middle of the 18th century or c) the end of the 18th century?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And I said: the middle of the 18th century.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Wrong I'm afraid! It was towards the end of the 18th century.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I have nothing good in my life at the moment.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Shall we take a look at the vocabulary too?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Sure. The first word we had was movement - a movement is 'a group of people working together to support an idea'. Can you think of any modern day movements, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The environmental movement is very strong and popular at the moment, as is the movement for equality – gender equality, for example. And the next word we had was zeitgeist - now, a zeitgeist literally means 'the spirit of a particular time'. What would you say that the zeitgeist is these days, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, I think there's a focus on personal freedom. There's environmental concern, and of course, let's not forget the rise of social media. The next word we had was benchmark – a benchmark is 'a standard from which other things are judged'. If you were looking for a new house, Neil, what would your benchmark be?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, my current house has a garden and it has somewhere I can park my car, so that would be the benchmark for a new house. It would have to have that at least, and more. Next we have idealised – an idealised thing is 'an often imagined, perfect version of something'. Now, what three things would exist in an idealised world for you then, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I would say, personal freedom, religious tolerance and free ice-cream for everybody on a daily basis. Neil Brilliant! Ok!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Next we have nitty-gritty – the nitty-gritty is 'the important or practical detail involved in a situation or thing'. Now, getting married is supposed to be a wonderful thing, but what about the nitty-gritty of the ceremony, Neil. Give us a few examples!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, you have to decide who's going to sit next to who, who to invite, the food  -  some people don't like this, some people don't like that. You've got to get the flowers right. Oh, there's so much to think about – makes you think that marriage might be flawed … and flawed is a thing which is 'imperfect in some way'. London's a great city, but how do you feel about it, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, I think it's flawed in the way that the public transport could use an upgrade- there's never enough space on the carriages. Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And we are on social media too. Make sure to visit our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
